characters: WRITTEN ON THE SCREEN IN ALL COLORS OF THE RAINBOW

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dark phrases of womanhood, of never having been a girl. Half-note scattered without rhythm. INT. JUANITA’S APARTMENT — DAY 2 JUANITA a nurse dressed in green and relentless volunteer stands in the kitchen of her modest apartment watering a plant. She goes back to her table where she has several hundred flyers printed. The flyers read, “Free Clinic Seminars on Thursday”.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No tune distraught. Laughter fallin’ over a black girl's shoulders. It’s funny. It’s hysterical. The melodylessness of her dance. Don’t tell nobody, don’t tell a soul. She’s dancing on beer cans and shingles.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JOANNA’S APARTMENT - DAY 3 JOANNA a high powered business woman stands in her posh penthouse apartment high above Manhattan, she is getting ready for work. Dressed in red, she stands in her closet. Her husband CARL, in silhouette is in the shower. We see him in the distance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joanna picks his pants up off the floor, a card falls out. She picks the card up and looks at it, then puts it back in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This must be the spook house. Another song with no singers, lyrics no voices and uninterrupted solos, unseen performances. Are we ghouls? Children of horror?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ALICE’S APARTMENT - DAY 4 ALICE a religious fanatic walks to a closet in her small run down apartment. She sits in her closet and starts praying. She’s dressed in all white, lighting candles on a makeshift altar.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The joke? Don’t tell nobody, don’t tell a soul. Are we animals? Have we gone crazy? INT. KELLY’S APARTMENT -— DAY 5 KELLY, an overworked social worker, is looking at a pregnancy test stick in the bathroom of her modest apartment. It’s negative. She is dressed in blue. DONALD her husband enters. She quickly puts it in the trash can and tries to hide her frustration. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can’t hear anything but maddening screams and the soft strains of death. And you promised me. You promised somebody. Anybody. Sing a black girl's song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A graduation is in full swing. We see NYLA dressed in purple, as she receives her diploma. Her mother ALICE beams with pride from the front row. Alice is dressed in all white with a cross on and a huge bible. Her older sister TANGIE dressed in orange looks uninterested as she looks at a one of the male teachers making eyes at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bring her out to know herself. To know you, but sing her rhythms caring, struggle.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hard times sing. Her song of life. She’s been dead so long, closed in silence so long. INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT — DAY 7 CRYSTAL lays in the bed in a very run down apartment BEAU WILLIE is having sex with her. Her brown dress is pushed up above her thighs. A tear rolls down her face.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She doesn’t know the sound of her own voice, her infinite beauty. She’s half-note scattered without rhythm, no tune. Sing her sighs... Sing the song of her possibilities. Sing a righteous gospel. Let her be born. Let her be born and handled warmly.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE/JUANITA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And this is for colored girls who have considered suicide but moved to the ends of their own rainbows.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. TANGIE’S APARTMENT —- KITCHEN - DAY 8 Tangie sits at the kitchen table of her small urban apartment. She is writing in her journal. She takes some orange butterflies out of her hair and put them in a box. A half-dressed man comes out of the bedroom. We realize that it’s the same man that she was making eyes with at the graduation.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You got anything to eat?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: You’‘1l have to go now. I've got lot of work to do and I can’t with aman around. She walks over and gives him his pants. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here are your pants. There’s coffee on the stove. It’s been very nice but I can’t see you again.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What did you say to me?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: You got what you came for. Didn’t you? He mumbles as he puts on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t possibly wake up with a strange man in my bed.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Is that why you been out here all night.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you go home. I’m sure your wife is looking for you. He glares at her for a second.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. He walks out and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Yes, get your little dick, no fucking ass, out of here. EXT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY 9 Man # 1 walks out the apartment building. Juanita opens the back door of her car. She is trying to remove a plant from her backseat. Kelly stands at the door on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Kelly Watkins from Child Welfare. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 GOLDENROD REVISED 5.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I’m looking for Crystal Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What do you want with her?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I don’t have time to play these games Ms. Wallace. Open the door or I’m coming back with the police.
Kelly is buzzed into the apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Hold it please. Kelly holds the door.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT BUILDING - HALLWAY - DAY 10 Kelly enters. She looks for the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Great. Kelly walks to the stairway and looks up. Crystal looks down from the fifth floor.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No elevator?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: It’s a walk up. Kelly starts the walk up the stairs. She passes Juanita holding the plant and standing at a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: I know you’re in there Frank. Open the door. She looks down at the bottom of the door seal. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 GOLDENROD REVISED 6.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got a woman in there? Franklin. You know what...Fine Frank. Fine, I’ve had enough of this, I'm sick of your shit and Without any assistance or guidance from you I have loved you assiduously for eight months, two weeks and a day. I have been stood up four times. I’ve left seven packages on your doorstep, forty poems, two plants and three handmade note cards. And I left town so I could send them. You have been no help to me on my job. You call at 3:00 in the morning on weekdays. Charming, charming. But you are of no assistance. I want you to know this was an experiment to see how selfish I could be. If I could really carry on, to snare a possible lover. If I was capable of defacing myself for the love of another. If I could stand not being wanted when I wanted to be wanted. And, I cannot so, with no further assistance and no guidance from you. I am ending this affair. She reaches into her purse and takes a note card. She sticks it into the plant.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s a note that is attached to a plant I've been watering since the day I met you. You may water it your damn self. INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT BUILDING - HALLWAY - DAY 11 Gilda comes out of her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: Is somebody coming up?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: You know somebody coming up Ms. Gilda. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 GOLDENROD REVISED 7.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: Who is it? Crystal gives her a look. She hears a noise coming from her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that Beau Willie? Crystal gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you get my mail when you go downstairs?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Sure I’ll get it. Apartment 515 door opens Tangie sweeps dust into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: You’re gonna clean that up.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: It's dust. It will blow away.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: Everything don’t blow like you. You got a lot of men coming through your house.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Why you jealous cause you don’t have no men COMING at all. Mind your business. Tangie turns to go into her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your old ass better leave me alone. You have been the bain of my existence since they voted you apartment manager. Tangie goes into the house and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: I can’t stand that girl. Just a tramp.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I’‘1l talk to you later Ms. Gilda. Kelly makes her way to the fifth floor. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 12 GOLDENROD REVISED 8.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. Gilda goes into her apartment. She slowly closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I gotta start exercising.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: You just did. Kelly is breathing hard. CRYSTAL (CONT’D) Can I get you some water?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Please. Crystal goes into her apartment. Kelly follows.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT — DAY 12

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I told the doctor that she was fine. It’s just a little bruise. Kelly looks around the small but neat apartment. Crystal gives her a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Thank you. I understand that but, any time a child is repeatedly seen in an emergency room, we have to do a home visit. Where are your children? Crystal goes into the small bedroom. Kelly sees cigarette smoke and feet hanging from a bed in the bedroom. She can hear a very loud TV. Crystal comes out with the kids and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that the children's father?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Yes. Kelly looks at the kids. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I’‘1l need to speak to him.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: He’s asleep.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You must be Kenya. Hello. The kids don't respond.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name is Kelly. I like your shirt. Can you talk to me for a second? Do you remember when you went to see the doctor the other day? How did you hurt yourself? Beau Willie comes out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I’m Kelly Watkins from Child Welfare.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Child welfare?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Damn Government. I called them months ago to get veterans benefits. I can’t get a case worker. How the fuck the government gonna send you down here about some kids? I been asking them bastards. I defended this damn country, so you can have that job, and they send you down here with this bullshit. Get the fuck out of here. Coming here about some damn kids. Sensing she is not safe Kelly quickly gathers her things INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT BUILDING - HALLWAY - DAY 13 Crystal quickly closes the door. Kelly looks at the kids as the door is closing. Gilda opens the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: (whispering) It ain't her that’s hurting them kids. It’s him. I baby sit ‘em, I know. I can hear everything through this wall. That's why I called you.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You called.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: Yes. She can’t protect them from him. Ever since he came back from the war he’s been crazy. And he drinks like a fish. Do her a favor take them children. He came home crazy as hell and tried to get veterans benefits to go to school & they kept right on puttin’ him in remedial classes. He couldln’t read wortha damn, so Beau cussed the teachers of holdin him back & got himself a gypsy cab to drive, but his cab kept breakin down and the cops was always messin wit him. Crystal went and got pregnant again and Beau most beat her to death when she told him, she still gotta scar under her right tit where he cut her up. Still Crystal went right on and had the baby, so now Beau Willie has two children, a and there waz no air. Beau Willie opens the door. Gilda quickly closes her door. Kelly walks down the stairs. She can almost feel Beau Willie staring at her. She looks back at Beau Willie. She hurries out. INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT BUILDING - HALLWAY - DAY 14 Alice walks up the stairs past Kelly. She knocks on Tangie’s door. Tangie opens it.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I need some money.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: For what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Things.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: I gave you money on the first.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: There are things I need.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Do you know how hard it is for me to come over here and ask you for anything? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Then stop doing it.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't, if I didn't have to.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: What do you need money for?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You do this to taunt me. You are just as evil as my father was. Just evil.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Granddaddy put me in charge of his little will because he knew you would give all of it to that cult.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It’s not a cult. You would know that if you came and spent some time at the Temple of Elohim.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: I'm not giving you any money.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You will burn in hell child.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Why is it when I give you money I’m blessed of Elohim and when I don't I'm going to burn in hell?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I pray for you that you find God through the mist of the distances that Satan has put in your heart. He has lured you to him through deception, through the dark forces. Don’t let them take your body. Tangie starts closing the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Repent! Repent!

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Bla, Bla, Bla, Bye Alice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 15 GOLDENROD REVISED 12.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She closes the door. Alice exits towards the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY 15 Alice comes out of the apartment building and walks down the street handing out “Jesus Saves” tracks.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Praise Elohim. People ignore her. Yasmine and Bill pass her.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Repent children. Yasmine takes a track.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Alice looks at her. Then she looks at Bill.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Are you ready to meet Elohim.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I'm straight lady, thanks. She looks at Yasmine.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Be careful of the dark seekers. He’s darkness. Just evil. She gives her a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The golden city awaits you. Alice walks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You just bought your way out of hell.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: I guess I did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Anyway, go on you were talking about your girls.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: It’s so great. You should meet some of them they have so much hope. And they’re getting that from dance.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Look how your face lights up when you talk about them.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: I know, they excite me. You know most of my kids graduate from high school and go on to college.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That's great. He looks at her for a second.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Everyday since I met you two weeks ago we walk this route. I go to work, you go to your dance class and you never answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Bill I told you.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Do you know how much courage it took for me to step to you ona crowded subway. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: I just got out of a bad relationship.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to marry you. I just want to take you out to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: I'm going to be late for my class.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: See. So that’s how you are. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 16 GOLDENROD REVISED 14.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You’re one of those women that will only give. You won’t let people give to you.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Ok, dinner tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: 8 o'clock tonight.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Ok. See ya tonight. The two go in different directions on the street.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It's going to be great.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. COMMUNITY CENTER - YASMINE’S DANCE STUDIO - DAY 16 Nyla is in a dance class with eight other girls. The girls are doing their warm-ups.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: It was graduation night and I was the only virgin in the crowd. Bobby Mills, Martin, Jerome, Sammy Yates, Eddie Jones and Randy. All cousins. They pick me up ina black Buick. Smelling of alcohol and ladies in heat. We rambled from Camden to Mount Holly laughing at the afternoon's speeches. Our tassels dangling from the rear view mirror. Nyla stretches.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Climbing different sort of project stairs. We went to a party and I got drunk and couldn't figure out whose hand was on my thigh. But it didn’t matter because these cousins, Martin, Eddie, Sammy, Jerome and Bobby was my sweethearts alternately since the seventh grade. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REVISED 15.
dialogues.text: 16 Nyla and the other girls stretch. And dance about. All the girls seem to be listening.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The party got crazy so me and Bobby left the party before the police came. We were in the backseat of his old Buick. And girl Bobby started looking at me. Yeah, he started looking at me real strange. Like I was a woman or something and started talking real soft in the backseat. By the time the sun was coming up I couldn't stop smiling. Yasmine walks in.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You gave it up in a Buick?

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: You better be talking about a ride to school.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Yes we were.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Have you done your warm ups?

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Great. Are you ready to begin. The girls say yes.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Positions, from one. And two, and three and again. Nyla and spin. Nyla runs out of the room and onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep doing your warm up girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows her out to the street.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Are you ok? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 18 19 GOLDENROD REVISED 16.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm just nauseous. I don't know what it is.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: I think you’re just nervous about college and being on your own. I’ve seen this before. You’1l be fine. You're a smart girl. Come on I’‘1l get you a ginger ale. They walk and almost bump into Donald.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: He gets into his police car with Renee.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Thanks. Donald drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Renee sits next to him drinking coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Who can understand women?

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: But you're a woman.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: No, I'm a woman and I date women. And I don't have any answers.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: What good is having a lesbian to ride around with all day if you can’t give me some insight on the female mind from a same sex point of view. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 20 GOLDENROD REVISED 17.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: That's not fair I helped you get out of the dog, house when you forgot your anniversary didn't I? Renee sees a car in an alley.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Yes you did.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Hey stop, back up. They see a BMW parked in an alleyway with the windows steamed up.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: That's a really nice car for this neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two officers walk up to the car on opposite sides and tap the glass.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Get out of the car. Two men get out of the car buckling their pants.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: You’re under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Indecent exposure.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: We weren't doing...

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: I saw you sir.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Yeah and unfortunately I did too. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: You have the right to remain silent.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Wait, wait...Look I can’t go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Then, you should have gotten a room.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Any needles in your pockets? Donald walks Carl to the back seat of the squad car.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Children take this route home from school all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juanita sits in the lobby waiting area of the very upscale building. It is very modern and very cold with lots of hard edges and upright uncomfortable furniture. Katina an assistant comes out of an office.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Is she ready to see me?

dialogues.speaker: KATINA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, it'll be just a few more minutes. She goes to a table and pours a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where is Crystal?

dialogues.speaker: KATINA
dialogues.text: She called. She’s on her way.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Does it take this long to get tea? Katina quickly pours the coffee out and quickly makes tea as Juanita looks on.

dialogues.speaker: KATINA
dialogues.text: I’ve got it right here. I’m sorry she'll be right with you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 22 GOLDENROD REVISED 19.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Honey, I’m the one that’s sorry for you. Katina runs into the office.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BRADMORE PUBLICATIONS - JOANNA’S OFFICE - DAY 22 Joanna sits in a large office behind a glass desk it seems as if all of Manhattan is the view from both sides of the office windows. She sits talking to four people.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t understand this. This is a magazine not a web-site. Joanna clears her throat. Katina hands her some tea.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The readers want texture. Look at this ad, it says nothing. You all need to go back to the drawing board. Bring me something with style, contour. Ok, thank you. Four people exit the meeting. Joanna has a small cough. Crystal runs in.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Finally, you’re here. What happened this time? One of the children had a fever, the baby- sitter was late or you over slept.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I do have limits even for a very good assistant.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Where is the buy Katina?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: It's here. I left it on your desk I knew you would need it this morning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: And the st...

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: The stat report is attached. Also your nine o'clock is here.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: What nine o'clock? She looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s ten.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Last week you agreed to meet with Juanita Sims. She runs a nonprofit organization. Shall I send her in.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Fine. Katina goes out to get her.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, why do I take these beggar meetings. Juanita comes in as Katina and Crystal leave out.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Hi. Juanita Simms.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Hi. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: I’m so glad that you took this meeting. I’1l be quick because I know you're really busy. I was reading in your magazine about your upbringing and I just knew... Joanna seems to not be paying attention to her.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You would respond to this program. I’m a nurse and I started a free health and wellness clinic ina community center in one of the poorest neighborhoods in this city. As you know growing up poor like so many of us. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We never had health care or even talked about it. So I just wanted to educate women on their bodies and at the same time their mind and souls. You and me both were raised by single mothers so I know how that is.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: That's great. Where do I come in? Juanita hands Joanna a flyer, placing it on top of the document that she was distracted with. The two woman look at each other oddly for a second.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Well this is just a little nonprofit. And everything I've been doing, I've been doing on my own, out of my pocket, you know we get a small donation here and there.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Let me stop you, I give to Cancer, I give to Education, I give to Africa. Those are my charities of choice.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: And those are all great causes but there is so much need right here in our own community.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Our community, I think that we've all been afforded the same opportunities in this country and if these women, these people didn't do anything with their opportunities, it’s not my issue. I’m afraid I’m going to have to say no. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Thank you? Joanna leans into the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Crystal see Ms. Sims out please. Crystal comes in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Did she just...

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Right this way please.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: No. I sat in this damn lobby waiting an hour for you. Cool, you don’t want to give us any money I get that. But this attitude and disregard for people’s time and feeling is ridiculous. Does it take all of this for you to be that? Cause if it does, you might be paying too much. Juanita walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donald stands in the room Kelly paces a little. The doctor comes in.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Babe will you stop pacing.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: It’s ok.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: What if he says we can’t have children?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Baby that wouldn't be the end of the world.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I want to give you a child, Donald.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAVIS
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Hi. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAVIS
dialogues.text: Ok, so we got the lab results and the test results. He puts up an x-ray.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is why your haven't been able to conceive. Your fallopian tubes are scarred. We usually see this form when a pelvis infection that wasn't treated.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: What wasn't treated?

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh, should we speak alone.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: No, its fine.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAVIS
dialogues.text: An untreated STD can cause this issue. Donald looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: What about surgery?

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAVIS
dialogues.text: I honestly wouldn't recommend it. It's risky, you could end up needing to have a hysterotomy. Kelly walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Hey. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 25 GOLDENROD REVISED 24.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I just need to go to work.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: It’s ok baby.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You know how hard it is looking at all of these people who don't want children, I gotta go to work.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Ok I’1l see you at home later. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hotel is very trendy and new, likened to the W hotel franchise. The bar is a small area filled with people. Tangie is the bartender pouring drinks.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Let me have a double shot of vodka straight. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: You can tell a lot about a man by what he drinks.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that man over there is drinking a beer. He's broke, now the guy over there is drinking champagne trying to impress the lady but he doesn't know what a good bottle is so he bought the most expensive. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He laughs. GOLDENROD REVISED 25. 25

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The two guys over there are drinking from glasses with umbrellas. They are so flaming if they walk past a sprinkler it will go off.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. What does my drink say about me?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: It says you're married, here on business and want to get a buzz quickly so you can have a good time and forget about the wife at home.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Wow?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Dead on. So what are my chances.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Having a good time in your beautiful city.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Looking very good daddy.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: And just where can I go to have a good time?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Tell you what, I’m off in a few hours I could show you around if you're up for it.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I'd like that very much.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Tangie there is a black woman in the lobby who says she’s your mother. She won’t come in because this is a bar and of the devil. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 26 GOLDENROD REVISED 26.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Cover me. She goes out to the lobby of the nice hotel.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing at my damn job?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I need some money.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: I told you I wasn't giving you any money now get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I need three hundred and eighty five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I just need it.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Get out of here Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I have to have the patience of Job to deal with you, my daughter. You’re going to end up in the belly of the whale if you don't get your life right.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Security! A security guard walks over.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This customer has had too much to drink can you escort her out.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Ma’am would you come with us please. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 27 GOLDENROD REVISED 27.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You touch me I will bless you out with this oil, child boy.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 27 Crystal reads a bedtime story to the kids. Beau Willie comes in.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Hey. I kept the dinner warm for you.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah ok.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: How did it go?

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to try to look for a job today.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Ain't nobody trying to hire a veteran. Get me a drink. She gets him some water. He knocks it out of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the shit is that?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Water.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: I want a drink.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Beau maybe you shouldn't drink tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: You trying to say I got a problem. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: No, I’m saying you shouldn't drink tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: So you telling me what I should do now.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I'm telling you what I think. I'm not accusing you of anything. Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm not an alcoholic.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm trying Crystal.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I know that too, Beau. It’s just that you get so mad sometimes. I know the army did you wrong. I saw it. I'm on your side. I know why you get mad but baby when you drink you get out of control. So don't drink tonight do it for me. Ok.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Ok. You know I love you?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: You love me.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Of course I do.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Then why wont you marry me.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: We got more things to worry about then getting married.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: If you loved me you would. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I love you. Now come on and get some dinner in you. He gets up and goes to the kitchen. 29. 27

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. COMMUNITY CENTER - JUANITA’S FREE CLINIC - DAY 28 Juanita is talking to several women.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Ladies, these condoms are free. How many times have you heard your man say, “It don't feel the same” or “I ain't got nothing” when his ass ain't even been to a doctor. Make him use them. If you know how many young beautiful faces I see every day like yours at the hospital cause they didn't want to hurt the mans feelings. Shhhittt, hurt his feelings or let him go home hurting. Frank taps on glass in the door. Juanita looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I’1l be right back. Juanita goes out the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey, baby.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk to you. I haven't seen or heard from you in four days.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Baby, you know I drive that truck.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Don't give me that bullshit. I know you. Were you with her?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Baby, I miss you. 29 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 31 GOLDENROD REVISED 30.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: You miss me when she get tired of you. I'm to old for this Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: No, you don't.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: If you really love me, then leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don't hurt me like this.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Hurt you. Get out of here Frank. I got these ladies to talk to. Juanita goes back into the classroom as Frank looks at her. INT. COMMUNITY CENTER - JUANITA’S FREE CLINIC - DAY 30

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: When you use a condom it is important that you use a water based lubricant....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna sits at the table dialing on the phone. There is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Look I know we had a fight the other night but this silent treatment is not good for me. You were suppose to meet me at dinner. Call me. I’m starting to worry. We find Bill and Yasmine in the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: My papa thought he was Puerto Rican & we would have been except we were just regular Negros wit hints of Spanish. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So off I made it to this 36 hour marathon dance con salsa con Ricardo ‘Suggggggggggar’ Ray on southern boulevard. It was up up up up up stairs and stairs and lotsa hallway wit my colored New Jersey self. Didn’t know what anybody was saying except if dancin waz proof of origin I was jibarita herself that nite. I kept smilin and right on steppin. If he could lead I waz ready to dance. If he couldn't lead I caught this attitude. I'd seen Rosa do and would not be bothered I waz twirlin hippin givin much quick feet and bein a mute cute colored Puerto Rican. Bill laughs. As we pan over to Joanna.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Are you ready to order?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You know Danny I think I'm going to go home. Can you have my driver pull around please.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you. INT. ALICE’S APARTMENT - EVENING 32 Nyla is cooking dinner. Alice walks in and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Hey mamma.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Angel.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: I know you’re tired.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Come on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nyla kneels down and takes off Alice's shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Thank you. My sweet baby. You are nothing like your sister. Here. She gives her some money. Nyla looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: This is only thirty-eight dollars.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I know. I tried to get more but your sister wouldn't give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Maybe you shouldn't have told her it was for me.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I didn't tell her what it was for, but you know I wasn't going to lie. You know she can’t stand you. You've always been so much better then her. If she knew that it was for you to better yourself she would never give it to me. Your sister is so wicked. She holds that wallet like its Jacob holding on to an angel.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Why did grandpa put her in charge of the money when he died?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: To nail me to the cross. That's why he only gives me a thousand dollars a month. He wants to keep his foot on my neck even in death. Don't you worry I'1l figure out something. Can I talk to your dance teacher to see if I can pay it over time?

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: No, don't. She won’t do that. If I don't get that money Ms. Yasmine says she can’t get me the application for the my scholarship

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I know. I know, Elohim will make a way.  GOLDENROD REVISED 33. 33 EXT. YASMINE’S APARTMENT -NIGHT 33 Bill and Yasmine are walking down the street.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: And that's how it started. I can tell you love dance.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: I love dance more than I waz mad uh-huh, uh-huh, more than when I discovered Archie Shepp & subtle blues don't cha know I wore out the magic of juju heroically resisting being possessed. Oooccooc000000h the sounds sneakin in under age to slug’s to stare at'a real ‘artiste’ ans every word outta imamu’s mouth waz gospel. And if Jesus couldn't play a horn like Shepp wazn’t no need for colored folks to bear no cross at all and dance is my thank-you for music and I love you more than dance more than Aureliano Buendia loved macondo more than Hector Lavoe loved himself. More than the lady loved gardenias. More than Celia loves Cuba or Graciela loves el son more than the flamingoes love bein pretty. Te amo mas que te amo mas que, we’re here. I had the best time.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: See I told you.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: It's getting late.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Ok, good night. He leans in and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Good night. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Maybe for our next date you can cook. Help a brother save some money.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: You know what? I had such a good time I will do that.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Ok, go on in I want to make sure you're safe.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Ok. Such a gentlemen. That's a good thing. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Bye. He turns and walks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 34 INT. TANGIE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 34 Tangie and MAN #3 burst through the door drunk.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: No wait. She is taking off his clothes and hers too.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Come on daddy.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Look I gotta to tell you something. She is all over him.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I only have about eighty dollars on me.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: That's all I have. If it’s more we can go to the ATM?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: You think I'm a hooker?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Damn I'm sorry, I’m drunk. He starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: What’s funny?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I guess I'm just old fashion. What kind of woman picks a man up ina bar and takes him back to her place, if she's not a hooker?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: One that likes to fuck. He starts to laugh even harder.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't laugh at me. He laughs harder.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't laugh at me.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but this is some sick shit. You pick me up bring me back here to screw me. And you don't think this is cool. Wow, women have changed. I'm from the south, sorry. I'm just used to a women being...women. What kind of woman does that?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: You men have such a double standard. You can do it but, a woman can’t. Get out. Get out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 GOLDENROD REVISED 36.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: That's a good idea. Maybe this is for the best, because it seems to me that you do this too often to be healthy.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: You think I have some kind of disease?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: If it ain't in your body, it's definitely in your head.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Mothafucka you got five seconds to be on the other side of that door. Man #3 exits to the door.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CRYSTALS’S APARTMENT BUILDING - HALLWAY - NIGHT 35 Man #3 goes down the steps laughing. Gilda opens her door and looks at the man. Tangie stands at her doorway.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: You ain't one to judge me you son of a bitch. She looks at Gilda.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't you say a word.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: A Word. Gilda closes her door.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Bitch.... Tangie sees Nyla walking up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Why won’t you just give her some money. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 36 GOLDENROD REVISED 37.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: I make sure her rent is paid and that she has groceries. What more does she want? I'm not giving her money to give to them people. Tangie and Nyla enter the apartment. INT. TANGIE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 36

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: She needs some money.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: She walks Look, I have to pay my college application fees.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: I got a scholarship to college but I have to pay the application fees. And she didn't want to tell you that, because she knew you wouldn't do it if you knew it was for me.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: How much money?

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Three hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Girl, you think I'm Boo Boo the fool? That don’t sound right at all.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: It’s true.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: I'm not giving you any money.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Mamma was right about you. You’re evil. away as Tangie looks at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Hey hold up. You been fucking.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: What? No I haven't?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Yes, you have I can see it in your face. You’re pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Everybody is not like you Tangie.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you are little sister.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mama’s so proud of you. Wait till she finds out you pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: I'm not pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: I don't know how you gonna go to school like that. Mama is gonna die, I can’t wait. I cannot wait. Tangie starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He didn't use a condom. Baby you have to use a condom. I remember the first time I got pregnant. I was so scared. I went to this apartment on 138th. It was a red building in the middle of the block. Down a back alley. Apartment 331. I couldn't afford to go to no clinic. I wasn't pregnant anymore. Nyla walks out of the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 37 INT. CARL AND JOANNA’S APARMTENT - BEDROOM - NIGHT 37 Joanna is getting ready for bed when Carl walks in.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Hi. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 38 GOLDENROD REVISED 39.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I have been calling you all day.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yeah I know. My battery died.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: And you couldn't call me from another phone and tell me that. Do you know how worried I was. I was about to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I'm fine. INT. CARL AND JOANNA’S APARMTENT - BATHROOM - NIGHT 38 He goes straight to the shower. She follows him.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Is this about the fight we had the other night?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: No, Joanna. I told you my battery was dead.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You’re still angry with me. I can hear it in your voice.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I'm not angry.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Good, because you don't have a right to be.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Well you could have told me.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Excuse me, just as you should have told me that you were moving two hundred thousand dollars of my money into a stock that you didn't even check with me about.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: It’s always you and your money.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I earn it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 39 GOLDENROD REVISED 40.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I am a broker. Everyone at my firm knows who you are. It’s embarrassing to me to not be able to make decision as the man of this house. So I did it. I said I was sorry and I'm not talking about this shit anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Good, then don't talk, listen. We’ve only been married for three years. I know I have trust issues, but you making choices without checking with me is not helping.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: You not only have trust issues, you have control issues. He gets into the shower.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Don't walk away from me. Fine. Joanna exits.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DONALD AND KELLY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 39 Kelly sits in the apartment when Donald comes in.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Hey, you're up late. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I can’t sleep. How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: My day was where I left it.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I understand that. Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOLDENROD REVISED 4l.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Don't you want to know what happened?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Do you want to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: A boyfriend in college. Had gonorrhea didn't tell me. I found out eight months later from having the worst cramps in my life. And now I can’t give you a child.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: You give me way more than I need, baby. Donald kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll figure this out. You know I love you.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Then let's keep building from that. Ok?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 40 EXT. JUANITA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 40 Juanita drives up to her place, she gets out of the car. Frank is sitting on the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Just leave me alone Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Can we just talk? Juanita walks past him and goes into her apartment. Frank follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. JUANITA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 41

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Go home. Oh that’s right, you don't have a home to go to.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Somebody told me you moved out of your apartment. What did you do, move back in with her?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: I'm sick of all your lies and shit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry baby. I don't know why I keep going back. But if you want to know the truth, this time, I felt different when I was there. I was thinking about you all the time. If I can’t have you I don't know what I'm gonna do.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: What would I look like letting you back in my life after all the advice I give to the women at my clinic.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Baby.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: No Frank, you listen, every time I let you move back in here you do the same thing. And every time I come home and you're not here. I check the closet to see of your things are gone. I gotta set an example for my women.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This ain't got nothing to do with them. This is about me and you babe. You help them, now help me.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Help you do what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 42 GOLDENROD REVISED 43.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Get to a place in myself where I don't need nobody but you. You say you want honesty baby I'm giving you the truth. He hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: Why didn't you just say that in the first damn place? He kisses her on her neck.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm tired of trying to love you Frank. You ought to just leave.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let me stay, you gone let me stay.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA
dialogues.text: No, go. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frank, Frank. He kisses her neck.

dialogues.speaker: JUANITA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got some condoms? INT. BRADMORE PUBLICATIONS - JOANNA’S OFFICE - DAY 42 Crystal is busy around the office.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Hey, I called Dr. Jackson and she can see you this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KATINA
dialogues.text: Your husband is here. Carl comes in with flowers. Crystal leaves.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Hi. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Hey. What a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I just came by to tell you that I'm sorry for the way I've been acting the last few days. You are so right, I shouldn't have taken that money without telling you. I really thought I was helping you...us. I thought it would earn a lot of interest and you would be proud of me. And I don't blame you for taking my name off the accounts. It’s your money. I'm sorry. Baby, I really love you. And I'm going to do better.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: And I got tickets to the opera tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You’re going to take me to the opera?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Oh, you must really be sorry if you’re going to sit through it. What did you call it the last time we were there? Chinese water torture?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: For you I will. He leans in to kiss her. She coughs. They both

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Sorry. laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. COMMUNITY CENTER - YASMINE’S DANCE STUDIO - DAY 43 Yasmine walks in and sees flowers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Who’s that from?

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Just a guy I had dinner with he's really nice. Can I help you with something.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm here to pay for the college applications.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, I'm Tangie, Nyla’s my sister. She said that there was three hundred dollars that she needed to pay for a application or something.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about. The classes are free.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: That little slut. Thank you. Tangie turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apartment building is run down and dilapidated. Drunks and addicts fall out of apartment doors. We hear lots of yelling and noise as Nyla knocks on a door. A man opens the door as a pit bull barks in the doorway. He holds him tightly with a chain, as Nyla walks in. He looks at her and closes the door. Babies cry in the background. INT. ROSE’S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY A44

dialogues.speaker: NYLA
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Nyla.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You don't have a name girl. Nyla looked around the room. It doesn't look clean. She has great reservation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Sit there on the table. Come on girl. She stands there for a while as Rose goes on to something else. She pours bleach on the table and into a bucket.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you still standing here for? Where’s my money? She hands her fifty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get on the table. She prepares her instruments. A train passes, seeming to be just outside the window. Nyla looks in the trash can and sees several empty vodka bottles. There are beer bottles on the counter and a half filled whiskey bottle sitting next to an empty glass with melting ice.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve done this a million times relax. Young girls get out there in the world and they have to come see me. That world is something. I useta live in the world then I moved to Harlem and my universe is now six blocks. Rose is pulling out all kinds of instruments that are not sterilized at all. She puts them in the bleach bucket.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A tunnel with a train I can ride anywhere, remaining a stranger. Nyla looks at her confused. Then at the instruments.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I could stay alone. A woman in the world then, but I moved to Harlem. I come in at dusk, stay close to the curb. Round midnight praying won’t no young man think I’m pretty. In a dark morning wouldn’t be good, not good at all to meet a tall short black brown young man fulla his power in the dark, in my universe of six blocks. Straight up brick walls women hanging outta windows like old silk stockings. Cats crying, children giggling. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A tavern with red curtains. Bad smells, kissing ladies smiling and dirt sidewalks spitting. Men cursing. Come here bitch. Can't you see this five dollars. I usedta live in the world. Really be in the world free and sweet talking. Good morning and thank you and nice day. Uh-huh I can’t now. I can’t be nice to nobody. Nice is such a rip-off. I usedta be in the world. A woman in the world I hadda right to the world. Then I moved to Harlem for the set-up of a universe six blocks of cruelty piled up on itself. A tunnel closing. Open your legs. INT. YASMINE’S APARTMENT -—- NIGHT 47.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 45 Yasmine’s apartment is very Afrocentric. Its small and colorful. There is a futon, coffee table, and lots of books on a book shelf. Lots of posters of famous African dancers Josephine Baker, Judith Jamison, Scheita, Alvin Ailey, and so on. Bill sits on the sofa. She stands in the kitchen. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Nice place.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What smells so good?

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: No, I'm cooking a Cuban feast for you my friend.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Let’s skip the dinner and go right for the desert. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOLDENROD REVISED 48.
dialogues.text: 45 He walks up to her and kisses her on her forehead. She does.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Hug me.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You do smell good.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Let me check the bread. You want wine?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You are all the wine I need. He tries to kiss her. She pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Bill come on, stop. We’re suppose to be having dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Come on, you want to. He starts to take off his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Bill...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Put your clothes on.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What, we’re both adults. I know why you asked me to come over here.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: No, no you've got it wrong. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 46 47 48 GOLDENROD REVISED 49.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Oh I see, you’re gonna put up a fight. So you can feel like a good girl in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: That’s not what I was thinking at all.... He grabs her and holds her around the waist tight.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop it. He tries to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You know you want me. You know it.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: Stop it. He slams her against the wall holding her wrist over her head with one hand and kissing her on the neck, squarely on top of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna and Carl sit and listen as The opera singers start to sing an opera called Pyramid. (Ntozoke’s poem translated to an Italian Opera.)

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. YASMINE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 47 Yasmine is fighting Bill off as. He is enjoying every violent moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl and Joanna watch the opera.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 49 50 51 52 53 GOLDENROD REVISED 50. INT. YASMINE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 49 Yasmine has stopped fighting and seems to be in shock with tears falling from her face she has gone limp. She looks at the clock on the wall. It seems to tick loudly. It reads 8:25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opera singers get to the climax of the opera. Carl looks out of the corner of his eye at a man that is looking back at him.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. YASMINE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 51 Bill is having an orgasm as Yasmine lays there unaffected. She looks at the clock it’s 8:28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna sits with a tear falling from her face. As the opera continues.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. YASMINE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 53 Yasmine sits up completely in shock and removed from the situation. She sits void of emotion pulling up the strap on her bra. Bill is laughing. It’s inaudible to her.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You want me to set the table. Yasmine shakes her head no. He gets down on his knees in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I knew you would enjoy it. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was good, wasn’t it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 54 GOLDENROD REVISED 51.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Yasmine nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's getting late, you still want to have dinner? She shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ok, I gotta work tomorrow anyway. I better get home and get some sleep. Lock the door behind me. Ok. Yasmine nods yes. As he leaves she runs to the door and locks it falling to the floor in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crystal walks over to Katina’s.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Where are you going for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: KATINA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. Joanna comes out of the office she starts to cough.

dialogues.speaker: KATINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tea?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yes Crystal. Where are the field stats?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: It’s in the report page seven. She slams the report on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Do you see it?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Oh no, I must have forgotten it at home. I took it to make sure it was right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 55 56 57 GOLDENROD REVISED 52.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I have a lunch meeting in forty five minutes. What do you propose I do?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I’‘1l get on the train right now and go get it.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: No, no, I'll be late, come on. I’1ll take you to your house.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT/EXT. JOANNA’S CAR - DAY 55 Crystal and Joanna pull up to the apartment. Crystal is reluctant to get out of the car. Joanna leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: You’re not getting out are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: No, will you hurry please. Joanna reaches into her purse. Crystal gets out of the car and looks around she quickly runs into the building.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JOANNA’S CAR - DAY 56 Joanna sits frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I hate coming to these kinds of neighborhoods. Are the doors locked?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am they are.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: It's hard to believe I grew up this way. INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT — DAY 57 As she walks into the apartment it is dark. An episode of Bonanza plays on the television in black and white. Beau Willie stands in the window smoking a cigarette. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 58 GOLDENROD REVISED 53.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He is looking down at the Mercedes and sees a man’s form in the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Did you pull up in that car?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s my boss.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: I thought you worked for a woman.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Who’s the dude in the front seat?

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: That's the driver.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: You think I'm crazy don't you? Crystal sees an empty vodka bottle on the table. Beau walks towards her. INT. GILDA’S APARTMENT - DAY 58 Gilda sits with the children when she hears a noise. She hears a picture fall off the wall and crash on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: KENYA
dialogues.text: What is that noise?

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: It'll be alright.

dialogues.speaker: KWAME
dialogues.text: Is that my mamma?

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you how I met my husband. His name was Toussaint. I was eight years old. The library was right down from de trolly tracks cross from the laundry-mat thru the big shining floors and granite pillars. Old St. Louis is famous for. I found Toussaint. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GILDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I knew I wasn't supposed to but I ran into the adult reading room and came across Toussaint my first black man. They hear Beau Willie yelling. The kids look teary.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Toussaint was a black man. A Negro like my Mama say. Who refused to be a slave. He spoke French and didn't let no white man to tell him nothing. I was sick of white folks so my imaginary...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT — DAY 59 We see close up shots of Beau Willie raising his hand and Crystal trying to get away from him. He throws her against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Toussaint said “Let’s go to Haiti”. I said awright. Then Toussaint and I took the Hodiamont Streetcar to the river last stop. That Was where we was gonna stow away on a boat for New Orleans and catch a creole fishing rig for Port-Au-Prince. INT. GILDA’S APARTMENT - SAME TIME 60 They hear another picture fall from the wall. The children start to cry.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: Then some ole boy jumped out in front of me and said, “Where you going little gal?” I said, “Who are you?” He said I'm Toussaint Jones. I said, “I am on my way to see Toussaint L’Ouverture in Haiti.” Are ya any kin to him? He don’t take no stuff from no white folks. They gotta country all they own and they ain’t no slaves. That silly ol' boy squinted his face all up. Looka heah girl, I am Toussaint Jones. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 61 62 63 GOLDENROD REVISED 55.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m right heah lookin' at ya and I don’t take no stuff from no white folks. Ya don’t see non round heah, do ya?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT - SAME TIME 61 Crystal is trying to shield herself from the blows, he is yelling at the top of his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. GILDA’S APARTMENT - SAME TIME 62 The children sit crying.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: And he sorta' pushed out his chest then he say, “Come on lets go on down to the docks and look at the boats.” I was real puzzled going down to the docks with my paper bag and my books. I felt Toussaint L’Ouverture leave and this Toussaint was the same ‘cept the ol’ one was in Haiti and this one wid me speakin' English and eatin' apples. Yeah, Toussaint Jones waz awright wit me. The noise stops, Gilda goes to the door and opens it. She is shocked to find Beau willie standing there, he grabs the children and takes them to the apartment and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT — DAY 63 Crystal comes out of the bathroom shocked to see that he has the children.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Bitch you hear me, you gonna be a whore all your life.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Beau Willie Brown. Do you want the children to see you act the fool again? (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 GOLDENROD REVISED 56.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you want Kwame to be brain damaged from you throwing him around? She grabs the kids and tries to protect them. She grabs a knife. He tries to grab the children.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get out or I’1l kill ya. I swear I’11 kill you He reaches for Kenya and Crystal grabs the little girl and holds her tight. CRYSTAL (CONT’D) Don’t you touch my children, muthafucker or I'll kill you. Beau steps back humble.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I don’t wanna hurt em. I just wanna hold em. I don’t wanna cause you no more trouble. I wanted to marry you and give ya things.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: What are you gonna give, a broken jaw. Niggah get outta here. He sits down and tears up. He lights a cigarette. Then he motioned for the children. Kenya pushes away and goes to her daddy.

dialogues.speaker: KENYA
dialogues.text: “Daddy, Daddy, be nice to Mommy cause, Mommy loves you and ya gotta be nice. He plays with the ribbons in her hair.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: See Crystal, I can be a good father now let me see my son. You are still hot, so strong. Didn't you get right up after that lil fight we had and went back to work. Come here Kwame. She loosens her grip on Kwame, then he walks over to Beau Willie. Crystal sits down and puts her hands in her head.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Beau, you gotta get some help.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beau jumps up laughing holding both the children in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Awright bitch, awright bitch. You gonna marry me. You gonna marry me.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Damn it Beau, I not going to Marry you. You‘re gonna be in jail. You gonna be under the jail for this. Now give me my kids. He kicks the screen out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: Your kids. What you trying to say they ain't mine..huh. You just a damn whore. Is that your man down there in the car? Are these his kids? Let me give him his kids...

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Beau NO!

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: You won’t marry me? They must be his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juanita walks to her car putting a box in the trunk. She is parked a few cars behind Joanna on the other side of the street. 65 INT. JOANNA’S CAR - DAY 65

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Where is this girl? 66 EXT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT - DAY 66 Tangie walks up the block headed home with another man.

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: But see, that's what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 67 68 69 70 71 GOLDENROD REVISED 58. EXT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT - DAY 67 Gilda comes out of the building screaming.

dialogues.speaker: GILDA
dialogues.text: Help her, help her...

dialogues.speaker: TANGIE
dialogues.text: What is wrong with this crazy old woman?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JOANNA’S CAR - DAY 68 Joanna sits looking at the commotion on the street.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: What’s going on? What is it? Gilda points up to the fifth floor window. Juanita and Tangie look up to see Beau hanging the children from the window. INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT — DAY 69

dialogues.speaker: BEAU WILLIE
dialogues.text: You gone marry me bitch!

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Beau, please, Beau! He holds the children out of the window. Crystal is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’‘1ll marry ya anything but, bring the children back in the house. INT./EXT. JOANNA’S CAR - DAY 70 Joanna gets out of the car to see what all the women are looking up at. INT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT - DAY 71

dialogues.speaker: CRYSTAL
dialogues.text: No, please. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 72 73 GOLDENROD REVISED 59.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The children are screaming and crying for Crystal. She is reaching for them when Beau lets go of the children. WINDOW POV of the women’s faces as the children fall. EXT. CRYSTAL’S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY 72 Juanita runs toward the children. As she is looking down into the camera all goes white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yasmine sits on a bed with a white curtain pulled ina very busy hospital.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: In my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: In your apartment, A friend is hard to press charges against.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: He’s not a friend.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: You'll hear things like. If you know him, you must have wanted it. A misunderstanding. You know these things happen. Are you sure you didn’t suggest?

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Had you been drinking?

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE
dialogues.text: I don't drink. A rapist doesn't have to be a stranger to be legitimate. Someone you never saw. But, if you’ve been in public with him, danced one dance, kissed him good-bye lightly with closed mouth. Pressing charges will hard be as hard as trying to keep your legs closed while five fools try to run a train on you. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 74 GOLDENROD REVISED 60.

dialogues.speaker: YASMINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These men friends of ours who smile nice stay employed and take us out to dinner. Lock the door behind you. And we are left with the scars being betrayed by men who know us. And expect like the stranger we always thought was coming that we will submit. We must have known. women relinquish all personal rights in the presence of a man who apparently could be considered a rapist especially if he has been considered a friend.
